Contents III
Overview
Part I: GEB
Introduction: A Musico-Logical Offering. The book opens with the story of Bach's Musical
Offering. Bach made an impromptu visit to King Frederick the Great of Prussia, and was
requested to improvise upon a theme presented by the King. His improvisations formed the basis
of that great work. The Musical Offering and its story form a theme upon which I "improvise"
throughout the book, thus making a sort of "Metamusical Offering". Self-reference and the
interplay between different levels in Bach are discussed: this leads to a discussion of parallel
ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.
Three-Part Invention. Bach wrote fifteen three-part inventions. In this three-part Dialogue, the
Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A tiny universe of meaningless symbols. I give the puzzle of trying to
prove a simple theorem in this universe, and then delve into the notions of formal systems as
mathematical models of axiomatic theories.
Chapter II: Meaning and Form in Mathematics. The puzzle is solved, and the MU-puzzle is
given a meaning. This leads to a discussion of the MU-puzzle's relationship to meaningful
statements in mathematics and then to the notions of formal systems as models of axiomatic
theories. The concept of “meaning” is then discussed, in the context of mathematics, physics, and
general knowledge.
Chapter III: Figure and Ground. The third part of the three-part invention. Here Zeno is
presented as a clever student who reacts to the first two parts by making clear that he doesn't
understand them. This leads to a discussion of the role of “figure” and “ground” in perception, and
analogously in mathematics and formal systems. The “Figure and Ground” puzzle is presented.
Chapter IV: Consistency, Completeness, and Geometry. The fourth part of the three-part Invention.
Here Zeno is at a loss for how to respond to the first three parts. The MU-puzzle
---

Contents III
Overview
Part I: GEB
Introduction: A Musico-Logical Offering. The book opens with the story of Bach's Musical
Offering. Bach made an impromptu visit to King Frederick the Great of Prussia, and was
requested to improvise upon a theme presented by the King. His improvisations formed the basis
of that great work. The Musical Offering and its story form a theme upon which I "improvise"
throughout the book, thus making a sort of "Metamusical Offering". Self-reference and the
interplay between different levels in Bach are discussed: this leads to a discussion of parallel
ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.
Three-Part Invention. Bach wrote fifteen three-part inventions. In this three-part Dialogue, the
Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A simple two-letter puzzle to illustrate the concept of formal systems.
A MU-puzzle consists of the letters M and U and a set of four rules that can be applied to them.
The MU-puzzle is a finite puzzle and cannot be solved. It is a simple example of a formal system,
and a system that is "incomplete." The idea of a formal system is introduced, and the concept of
formal systems as models of mathematics and as systems of reasoning.
The MU-puzzle is an example of a purely mathematical formal system. The puzzle is to show how
the string MU can be derived from the axioms M, and MU can be transformed according to the
four rules. The MU-puzzle is a puzzle and is an example of an undecidable formal system.
Chapter II: Meaning and Form in Mathematics. The MU-puzzle is a good example to explain
the concepts of "meaning" and "form" in mathematics. Meaning is not an inherent property of a
mathematical formal system, but depends on the way the system is used. The idea that formal systems
must be "given a semantics" is discussed, along with the notion of formal systems as abstract
mechanisms and as representations of something else.
Chapter III:
---

Overview
Part I: GEB
Introduction: A Musico-Logical Offering. The book opens with the story of Bach's Musical
Offering. Bach made an impromptu visit to King Frederick the Great of Prussia, and was
requested to improvise upon a theme presented by the King. His improvisations formed the basis
of that great work. The Musical Offering and its story form a theme upon which I "improvise"
throughout the book, thus making a sort of "Metamusical Offering". Self-reference and the
interplay between different levels in Bach are discussed: this leads to a discussion of parallel
ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.
Three-Part Invention. Bach wrote fifteen three-part inventions. In this three-part Dialogue, the
Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A simple version of Gödel's Incompleteness Theorem. The MU-puzzle
consists of three rules which are given. The puzzle is to discover, with the help of these rules, whether
M can be transformed into U. The MU-puzzle is a variation of the MIU puzzle posed by Hofstadter
in his book Gödel, Escher, Bach: A Mental Space Odyssey. The MU-puzzle is here presented as a
way to explain the MU-puzzle's relevance to Gödel's Incompleteness Theorem.
Two-Part Invention. Bach's two-part Invention is based on the theme of the first Invention, but
it adds a new twist. The first part is an ant fugue, and the second part is a canon by augmentation of
the ground. The two-part Invention is a way to present the idea of levels of description, which is
relevant to the discussion of computer systems. The two-part Invention is also a way to introduce the
notion of recursion, which is central to the MU-puzzle.
Chapter II: Meaning and Form in Mathematics. The story of the MU-puzzle is a way to get at the
problem of meaning and form in mathematics. The puzzle
---

Contents III
Overview
Part I: GEB
Introduction: A Musico-Logical Offering. The book opens with the story of Bach's Musical
Offering. Bach made an impromptu visit to King Frederick the Great of Prussia, and was
requested to improvise upon a theme presented by the King. His improvisations formed the basis
of that great work. The Musical Offering and its story form a theme upon which I "improvise"
throughout the book, thus making a sort of "Metamusical Offering". Self-reference and the
interplay between different levels in Bach are discussed: this leads to a discussion of parallel
ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.
Three-Part Invention. Bach wrote fifteen three-part inventions. In this three-part Dialogue, the
Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A tiny Fragment of a much larger system, the MU-puzzle, which
consists of the single string "MU" and four formal rules that transform strings. The puzzle is to
find a string that cannot be derived from MU using these rules. The MU-puzzle is a simple version
of Gödel's famous First Incompleteness Theorem, showing that within any sufficiently powerful
formal system, there are propositions that cannot be proved or disproved within that system.

Two-Part Invention. Bach's two-part invention in D minor, with the bass part written by
Herr Phantin. The two-part invention is a musical composition that is presented in two parts,
the first part by the organist and the second part by the violinist. The bass part is written in a
way that allows for great flexibility in the interpretation of the two parts. The invention is a
musical composition that is presented in two parts, the first part by the organist and the second
part by the violinist. The bass part is written in a way that allows for great flexibility in the
interpretation of the two parts.

Chapter II: Meaning and Form in Mathematics. The MU-puzzle is a tiny fragment of a much larger
system
---

throughout the book, thus making a sort of "Metamusical Offering". Self-reference and the
interplay between different levels in Bach are discussed: this leads to a discussion of parallel
ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.
Three-Part Invention. Bach wrote fifteen three-part inventions. In this three-part Dialogue, the
Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A Simple Formal System. MU- puzzle: four commandments, starting
string, and rules of production. MU- puzzle as an example of a simple formal system. MU-
puzzle as an example of a pure mathematical system. MU- puzzle as an example of a system
without meaning. MU- puzzle as an example of a system with potential for meaning.
Chapter II: Meaning and Form in Mathematics. From the MU-puzzle to the MU-puzzle: stepping
towards the MU-puzzle. MU- puzzle as an example of a system without meaning. MU-puzzle as an
example of a system with potential for meaning. MU-puzzle as a formal system. MU-puzzle as a
pure mathematical system. MU-puzzle as an example of a system without meaning. MU-puzzle as
an example of a system with potential for meaning.
Chapter III: Figure and Ground. The Distinction between "Figure" and "Ground" in Mathematics.
The MU-puzzle as an example of a system without meaning. MU-puzzle as an example of a system
with potential for meaning. MU-puzzle as a formal system. MU-puzzle as a pure mathematical
system. MU-puzzle as an example of a system without meaning. MU-puzzle
---

Overview
Part I: GEB
Introduction: A Musico-Logical Offering. The book opens with the story of Bach's Musical
Offering. Bach made an impromptu visit to King Frederick the Great of Prussia, and was
requested to improvise upon a theme presented by the King. His improvisations formed the basis
of that great work. The Musical Offering and its story form a theme upon which I "improvise"
throughout the book, thus making a sort of "Metamusical Offering". Self-reference and the
interplay between different levels in Bach are discussed: this leads to a discussion of parallel
ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.
Three-Part Invention. Bach wrote fifteen three-part inventions. In this three-part Dialogue, the
Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A tiny yet comprehensive system. The MU-puzzle consists of the
strings M, MU, and any theorem derived from the following four rules. This puzzle is a
didactic device to explain the notion of formal systems, which are at the center of Gödel’s
Theorem. The puzzle is simple yet highly instructive for understanding the nature of formal systems.
Two-Part Invention. A contrapunctus in the style of Bach's
... (and so on)

Contents III
Overview
Part I: GEB
Introduction: A Musico-Logical Offering. The book opens with the story of Bach's Musical
Offering. Bach made an impromptu visit to King Frederick the Great of Prussia, and was
requested to improvise upon a theme presented by the King. His improvisations formed the basis
of that great work. The Musical Offering and its story form a theme upon which I "improvise"
throughout the book, thus making a sort of "Metamusical Offering". Self-reference and the
interplay between different levels in Bach are discussed: this leads to a discussion of parallel
ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.
Three-Part Invention. Bach wrote fifteen three-part inventions. In this three-part Dialogue, the
Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A simple two-letter alphabet is set up, with four very short
formal rules, and the puzzle is to see if we can derive certain strings using the rules. It seems
deeply counterintuitive that one of the target strings cannot be derived, even though the system is
so simple. It is a question that seems to me to be about as hard as any question that can be
posed in the field of formal systems.
Chapter II: Meaning and Form in Mathematics. This is the longest chapter. It covers the
notion that meaning is not the same as form in mathematics. It discusses some formal systems and
their properties, including a proof that there is no formal system that can fully capture the
meaning or validity of mathematical statements. It also discusses how one can use the formal system
to define concepts, but without defining the meaning of those concepts in any absolute sense.
This is a key point in the understanding of formal systems.
Chapter III: Figure and Ground. The concepts of figure and ground are discussed, and how
they are used in art and music. The example given is the Contracrostipunctus, which is a
counterpoint piece that is very hard to follow. The idea is that the figure is presented as a

---

Overview
Part I: GEB
Introduction: A Musico-Logical Offering. The book opens with the story of Bach's Musical
Offering. Bach made an impromptu visit to King Frederick the Great of Prussia, and was
requested to improvise upon a theme presented by the King. His improvisations formed the basis
of that great work. The Musical Offering and its story form a theme upon which I "improvise"
throughout the book, thus making a sort of "Metamusical Offering". Self-reference and the
interplay between different levels in Bach are discussed: this leads to a discussion of parallel
ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.
Three-Part Invention. Bach wrote fifteen three-part inventions. In this three-part Dialogue, the
Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A simple formal system is presented, called MU. The MU-puzzle is
a problem in which the goal is to derive the string MU from the axioms and rules of the MU system.
The MU-puzzle is a good example of a simple formal system, and it is used to illustrate the concepts
of formal systems, consistency, completeness, and undecidability. The MU-puzzle is also used to
discuss the idea of randomness and mechanical reasoning.
Chapter II: Meaning and Form in Mathematics. The MU-puzzle is a good example of a formal
system, and it is used to discuss the concepts of meaning and form in mathematics. The MU-puzzle
is also used to discuss the idea of the relationship between formal systems and human understanding.
The MU-puzzle is also used to illustrate the idea of the relationship between formal systems and
human understanding.
Chapter III: Figure and Ground. The MU-puzzle is also used to discuss the concepts of figure and
ground in mathematics and logic. The MU-puzzle is also used to discuss the idea of the relationship
between formal systems and human understanding.

concepts of consistency, completeness, and

Offering. Bach made an impromptu visit to King Frederick the Great of Prussia, and was
requested to improvise upon a theme presented by the King. His improvisations formed the basis
of that great work. The Musical Offering and its story form a theme upon which I "improvise"
throughout the book, thus making a sort of "Metamusical Offering". Self-reference and the
interplay between different levels in Bach are discussed: this leads to a discussion of parallel
ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.
Three-Part Invention. Bach wrote fifteen three-part inventions. In this three-part Dialogue, the
Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A simple two-letter puzzle to illustrate the concept of strings, rules,
and derivations. The MU-puzzle consists of a single axiom: MU, and the single rule: if you
can append two letters to a string, you can do so. The puzzle is to figure out how to get to a string
that has "MUIIUM" as its last part. This is a simple yet powerful example of how formal systems
work.
Two-Part Invention. Bach's two-part invented music. The story of these two-part inventions
leads into a discussion of the MU-puzzle and of the idea of strings, rules, and derivations. The
Two-Part Invention is a dialogue between Achilles and the Tortoise, in which they discuss how
they can think about the MU-puzzle and of other formal systems.
Chapter II: Meaning and Form in Mathematics. The Tortoise and Achilles are back in conversation
about the MU-puzzle and the MU-puzzle's relation to formal systems. They discuss how formal
systems can represent things beyond the system itself, and how meaning can be assigned to
strings through the choice of interpretation. The Tortoise reminds Achilles of the MU-puzzle and
they explore the implications of the MU-puzzle for
---

Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as

of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A simple formal system is presented, which illustrates the concept of
a 'formal system' in a concrete and incisive manner. The puzzle is to find a way to derive the string
MU in the system. The MU-puzzle is given as an example of a "game" that is interesting in itself,
and also serves as an incisive example of the nature of formal systems. The MU-puzzle is
presented in detail, and the concept of 'formal systems' is fully clarified. The puzzle is thoroughly
discussed, and the reader is led through various attempts to solve it, until a complete analysis is
achieved.
Two-Part Invention. Bach's two-part invention is presented. The story of the Invention is told, and
the musical pieces are discussed. The two-part invention is given as an example of the way in
which the book is written: by the interweaving of different levels, and the interplay between the
different levels.
Chapter II: Meaning and Form in Mathematics. The concept of Meaning and Form in Mathematics is
discussed. The question of whether Mathematics is a purely formal exercise (as in the MU-puzzle),
or whether it has content, and what the nature of such content

Contents III
Overview
Part I: GEB
Introduction: A Musico-Logical Offering. The book opens with the story of Bach's Musical
Offering. Bach made an impromptu visit to King Frederick the Great of Prussia, and was
requested to improvise upon a theme presented by the King. His improvisations formed the basis
of that great work. The Musical Offering and its story form a theme upon which I "improvise"
throughout the book, thus making a sort of "Metamusical Offering". Self-reference and the
interplay between different levels in Bach are discussed: this leads to a discussion of parallel
ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.
Three-Part Invention. Bach wrote fifteen three-part inventions. In this three-part Dialogue, the
Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A simple formal system is presented, and the puzzle is to figure out why
it's impossible to derive certain strings from the axioms. It is presented as a MU puzzle. The
puzzle is used to introduce the concept of strings, the role of definitions, and the distinction between
meaning and form. The MU-puzzle is a contrived example, but it has the advantage of being
very simple.
Two-Part Invention. Bach's two-part invention is presented as a dialogue between Achilles and the
Tortoise, where they discuss various themes, including the idea that they are both moving, and
that they are never moving. This is a discussion of the paradoxes of infinity, and also of the
paradoxes of self-reference. The two-part invention is also an introduction to the idea of the
recursively self-referential nature of the MIU system. The two-part invention is presented as a
recursively self-referential dialogue, and it is used to illustrate the concept of recursion.
Chapter II: Meaning and Form in Mathematics. The puzzle of how it is that mathematical statements can
be true if they are not just tautologies. The concept of meaning is discussed, and the distinction
between form and content.
---

consists of strings of Ms and Us, and transformation rules. The puzzle is to see whether the string
MU can be derived from the axiom MIU. The puzzle is a simple version of Gödel's Incompleteness
Theorem. The MU-puzzle is presented as an example of a simple formal system, leading into a
more complex system.

requested to improvise upon a theme presented by the King. His improvisations formed the basis
of that great work. The Musical Offering and its story form a theme upon which I "improvise"

interplay between different levels in Bach are discussed: this leads to a discussion of parallel
ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.

Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A simple two-letter puzzle to illustrate the concept of strings, rules,
and derivations. It is a small "game" where the player starts with a string, and by applying certain
rules, tries to reach a target string. The MU-puzzle is a good example of how abstract concepts can
be made concrete, and how the action of "thinking" can be approached from first principles.
Sonata for Unaccompanied Achilles. Aria with Diverse Variations. A musical piece that is a
counterpoint of ideas, which also serves as an analogy for the concept of recursion. The story
surrounds the Tortoise and Achilles, who are trying to resolve a philosophical puzzle. The main
theme is the idea of self-reference and the paradoxes that arise from it.
Chapter II: Meaning and Form in Mathematics. The Tortoise and Achilles explore the nature of
meaning and form in mathematics. They discuss the MU-puzzle, the concept of formal systems, and
Gödel's incompleteness theorems. The discussion also touches on the relationship between meaning
and form, and the role of human intuition in mathematics.
Sonata for Unaccompanied Achilles. Aria with Diverse Variations. The musical piece serves as
an analogy

### Detailed Content

Contents III
Overview
Part I: GEB
Introduction: A Musico-Logical Offering. The book opens with the story of Bach's Musical
Offering. Bach made an impromptu visit to King Frederick the Great of Prussia, and was
requested to improvise upon a theme presented by the King. His improvisations formed the basis
of that great work. The Musical Offering and its story form a theme upon which I "improvise"
throughout the book, thus making a sort of "Metamusical Offering". Self-reference and the
interplay between different levels in Bach are discussed: this leads to a discussion of parallel
ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.
Three-Part Invention. Bach wrote fifteen three-part inventions. In this three-part Dialogue, the
Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A simple formal system is presented, called MU, in which a string of
letters M and U can be transformed according to specific rules. The puzzle is to find a derivation of
MU. The MU-puzzle serves as a concrete example for discussing the meaning of strings in formal
systems, the role of formal systems in mathematics, and the relationship between meaning and
form. The MU-puzzle is a stepping-stone towards the later chapters on recursive structures and
processes and on the MU-puzzle's connection to Zen.

Two-Part Invention. Bach's two-part invented Music for aBWV Violin Part and aBWV Cello Part.
The two-part invention is presented as a dialogue between Achilles and the Tortoise, in which the
Tortoise challenges Achilles to a race, and Achilles, being from Zeno's paradoxes, gives the
Tortoise a head start. The dialogue serves as a philosophical introduction to the concept of
infinity.

Sonata for Unaccompanied Achilles. Aria written by Bach for the organ, which is a single voice
without counterpoint. The Sonatas for Unaccompanied Achilles are presented to illustrate the
concepts discussed in the preceding chapters. The Sonatas are meant to be played by Achilles
---


---

Introduction: A Musico-Logical Offering. The book opens with the story of Bach's Musical
Offering. Bach made an impromptu visit to King Frederick the Great of Prussia, and was
requested to improvise upon a theme presented by the King. His improvisations formed the basis
of that great work. The Musical Offering and its story form a theme upon which I "improvise"
throughout the book, thus making a sort of "Metamusical Offering". Self-reference and the
interplay between different levels in Bach are discussed: this leads to a discussion of parallel
ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.
Three-Part Invention. Bach wrote fifteen three-part inventions. In this three-part Dialogue, the
Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A simple two-letter puzzle to illustrate the concept of formal systems,
postulates, interpretations, and derivations. It is a tiny version of the MU-puzzle. The MU-puzzle
consists of the single axiom "MI" and the four rules of production:
Rule 1: Add a "I" to the right of any string that has "MI" as a substring.
Rule 2: Double any string that ends with "I".
Rule 3: Remove a "I" from any string that has "MII" as a substring.
Rule 4: Delete any "II" that appears in a string.

The MU-puzzle is a puzzle to find a derivation of "MUII" from "MI" using the four rules above. It is
a very simple version of the MU-puzzle. The MU-puzzle is a way to get at the essence of
formal systems, which is what the MU-puzzle is about. It is a simple two-letter puzzle to illustrate
the concept of formal systems, postulates, interpretations, and derivations. The MU-puzzle is a
tiny version of the MU-puzzle. The MU-puzzle is a way to get at the essence of formal systems,
which is what the MU
---

requested to improvise upon a theme presented by the King. His improvisations formed the basis
of that great work. The Musical Offering and its story form a theme upon which I "improvise"
throughout the book, thus making a sort of "Metamusical Offering". Self-reference and the
interplay between different levels in Bach are discussed: this leads to a discussion of parallel
ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.

Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A simple formal system is presented, which I call MU. It is a
very MUDDY puzzle leading to an MUDDY Theorem. MU is a puzzle in which the player must
find a way to get from M to U using certain rules of concatenation. MU is a puzzle that is
incredibly simple, yet touches on weighty issues in the foundations of mathematics. MU is a
puzzle that I have used time and again in my lectures, and yet, as far as I know, no one has ever
solved it. MU is a puzzle that is a MUddle of MUddles.
Two-Part Invention. Bach's two-part inventions are like dialogues between two voices. The
Tortoise and Achilles are "invented" by Zeno as a way of illustrating Zeno's paradoxes. The
text is a dialogue between Achilles and the Tortoise, in which Achilles is trying to convince the
Tortoise of the truth of Zeno's paradoxes. The dialogue is a good example of the way in which
the Tortoise and Achilles "incarnate" the dialogues that are to come. The dialogue itself is a
good example of the way in which the Tortoise and
---

Contents III
Overview
Part I: GEB
Introduction: A Musico-Logical Offering. The book opens with the story of Bach's Musical
Offering. Bach made an impromptu visit to King Frederick the Great of Prussia, and was
requested to improvise upon a theme presented by the King. His improvisations formed the basis
of that great work. The Musical Offering and its story form a theme upon which I "improvise"
throughout the book, thus making a sort of "Metamusical Offering". Self-reference and the
interplay between different levels in Bach are discussed: this leads to a discussion of parallel
ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.
Three-Part Invention. Bach wrote fifteen three-part inventions. In this three-part Dialogue, the
Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A simple example of a Postulate System, called MU. The puzzle
consists of strings of M's and U's, and four rules for transforming them. The MU-puzzle is a
paradigm for the MU-puzzle: a puzzle where the goal is to see if a certain theorem (here, "MU") can
be derived from the given postulates (here, the four rules). The MU-puzzle is a way of explaining
the nature of formal systems, and is a very simple example (I) of a Postulate System.
Two-Part Invention. A dialogue in which Achilles and the Tortoise present the MU-puzzle and
their attempts to solve it. The dialogue discusses the nature of formal systems, the four rules, and
the problem of meaning in formal systems.
Sonata for Unaccompanied Achilles. A musical piece by Bach, which is written for a single
voice. It is a set of interconnected themes that are individually simple, but together form a complex
and beautiful whole. It is similar to the MU-puzzle in that it is a self-contained system where each
part is interdependent with the others. The idea of recursion and the interplay between the different
parts is central to both.
Chapter II
---

Overview
Part I: GEB
Introduction: A Musico-Logical Offering. The book opens with the story of Bach's Musical
Offering. Bach made an impromptu visit to King Frederick the Great of Prussia, and was
requested to improvise upon a theme presented by the King. His improvisations formed the basis
of that great work. The Musical Offering and its story form a theme upon which I "improvise"
throughout the book, thus making a sort of "Metamusical Offering". Self-reference and the
interplay between different levels in Bach are discussed: this leads to a discussion of parallel
ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.
Three-Part Invention. Bach wrote fifteen three-part inventions. In this three-part Dialogue, the
Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A contrived "game" of strings. The MU-puzzle consists of the single
axiomatic string "MI" and the following four rules of production: 
Rule 1: If a string ends with "I", you can add a "U" to the end. 
Rule 2: If a string has "III" somewhere in it, you can replace that with "U". 
Rule 3: If a string begins with "M", you can add a "I" to the beginning. 
Rule 4: If a string has "UUU" somewhere in it, you can replace that with "I". 
The puzzle is to find out if "MU" can be obtained as a theorem of the system. 
Chapter II: Meaning and Form in Mathematics. The Tortoise and Achilles discuss the MU-puzzle,
and by using an analogy to how meaning is constructed in mathematics, they come to an
understanding of how formal systems can represent concepts.
Chapter III: Figure and Ground. The Tortoise and Achilles discuss the MU-puzzle, and by using an
analogy to how meaning is constructed in mathematics, they come to an understanding of how formal systems can represent concepts.

Part I: GEB
Introduction: A Musico-Logical Offering. The book opens with the story of Bach's Musical
Offering. Bach made an impromptu visit to King Frederick the Great of Prussia, and was
requested to improvise upon a theme presented by the King. His improvisations formed the basis
of that great work. The Musical Offering and its story form a theme upon which I "improvise"
throughout the book, thus making a sort of "Metamusical Offering". Self-reference and the
interplay between different levels in Bach are discussed: this leads to a discussion of parallel
ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.
Three-Part Invention. Bach wrote fifteen three-part inventions. In this three-part Dialogue, the
Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A simple version of Gödel’s Incompleteness Theorem. The MU-puzzle
consists of strings of letters of M and U. The MU-puzzle is a problem to see if the string MU can
be derived from the axioms M, MU→U, and M→MSM. The MU-puzzle is a good example of
how a sufficiently powerful system cannot be complete; it can't prove all its truths; it has to be
open-ended. The MU-puzzle is presented in detail, and the idea of strings and theorems, and of
transformations and rules, is introduced. The computer as information processor is also presented.
Part II: Meaning and Form in Mathematics. The question is: How can we get meaning out of
something that is a meaningless jumble of symbols? This is the problem that the Tortoise and
Achilles encounter when Achilles decides to tackle the MU-puzzle. Meaning is the business of
interpreting, and the Formalist view (meaning is purely syntactic) is discussed. Then comes the
Ig Nobel prizes for 1984, with the story of a man who tried to cure his wife of an imaginary
disease by writing an essay to her. The
---

Contents III
Overview
Part I: GEB
Introduction: A Musico-Logical Offering. The book opens with the story of Bach's Musical
Offering. Bach made an impromptu visit to King Frederick the Great of Prussia, and was
requested to improvise upon a theme presented by the King. His improvisations formed the basis
of that great work. The Musical Offering and its story form a theme upon which I "improvise"
throughout the book, thus making a sort of "Metamusical Offering". Self-reference and the
interplay between different levels in Bach are discussed: this leads to a discussion of parallel
ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.
Three-Part Invention. Bach wrote fifteen three-part inventions. In this three-part Dialogue, the
Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A simple two-letter puzzle to illustrate the concept of strings and
rules. The MU-puzzle consists of the three axioms: M, MU, and the two rules: (1) If you
have a string ending with U, you can add a U. (2) If you have a string with consecutive Us, you can
remove one U. The puzzle is to find out if the string MIU can be obtained by applying these rules
repeatedly.
Chapter II: Meaning and Form in Mathematics. The MU-puzzle is a concrete example of an
axiomatic system: formal symbols, rules of inference, axioms. Meaning and formal properties in
mathematics, formal systems, and the MU-puzzle as an example.
Chapter III: Figure and Ground. The concept of figure and ground in mathematics and art, the
MU-puzzle as an example.
Chapter IV: Consistency, Completeness, and Geometry. The MU-puzzle is used to explain
the concepts of consistency, completeness, and their relevance to geometry and formal systems.
Chapter V: Recursive Structures and Processes. The MU-puzzle is used to explain recursion, self-
similarity, and fractals.
Chapter VI: The Location of Meaning. The MU-puzzle is used
---

of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A tiny Mid-Scale Computer Program. The MU-puzzle is a
simple formal system, which serves as an example for explaining the concept of 'formal systems'.
It is a contrived system of thought, which has much in common with the systems of which
mathematicians and logicians make study. The MU-puzzle is essentially a miniature model of a
theorem-proving machine. The MU-puzzle is designed to make the abstract notions of formal systems
concrete and accessible for non-mathematicians. The puzzle is to find a way to get from MU to
MUIIIMU in the fewest steps. The MU-puzzle is a very simple self-referential system. It is a
recursive puzzle, which is a puzzle about itself. The MU-puzzle is a puzzle that contains itself, which
leads to the question: How can we get from MU to MIU MIU MIU MU? The MU-puzzle is a
puzzle that is about itself, and the rules of the system are such that it is impossible to solve. The
MU-puzzle is a system that is Turing complete, and can be used to model a wide range of
computational systems.
...

formal system. The MU-puzzle is a simple version of Gödel's incompleteness theorem, and I
discuss that. The MU-puzzle is also a direct metaphor for the MU puzzle of Hofstadter's
GEB.

Contents III
Overview
Part I: GEB
Introduction: A Musico-Logical Offering. The book opens with the story of Bach's Musical
Offering. Bach made an impromptu visit to King Frederick the Great of Prussia, and was
requested to improvise upon a theme presented by the King. His improvisations formed the basis
of that great work. The Musical Offering and its story form a theme upon which I "improvise"
throughout the book, thus making a sort of "Metamusical Offering". Self-reference and the
interplay between different levels in Bach are discussed: this leads to a discussion of parallel
ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.
Three-Part Invention. Bach wrote fifteen three-part inventions. In this three-part Dialogue, the
Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A simple two-letter puzzle, which leads into an explanation of
meaning and form in mathematics.
Chapter II: Meaning and Form in Mathematics. Central to the book. The MU-puzzle is a
specific example of an abstract system, which we call a Formal System. We will discuss such
Formal Systems in general, and contrast them with Informal Systems.
Chapter III: Figure and Ground. Here, the MU-puzzle is used to shed light on the notions of
figure and ground in mathematics, as well as the notions of meaning and form in both mathematics
and music.
Chapter IV: Consistency, Completeness, and Geometry. Consistency and completeness of
Formal Systems. An example is given in Geometry, and the MU-puzzle is used to illustrate
Gödel's First Incompleteness Theorem.
Chapter V: Recursive Structures and Processes. Recursive vs. Convergent Thinking. The MU-puzzle
is a simple example of a Recursive Structure, and we go into depth on how to analyze such
Recursive Structures and Processes.
Chapter VI: The Location of Meaning. The puzzle is used to show that the notion of Meaning is
dependent on the particular medium. Various other examples are given, from mathematics to
music to language.
Chapter
---


---

Part I: GEB
Introduction: A Musico-Logical Offering. The book opens with the story of Bach's Musical
Offering. Bach made an impromptu visit to King Frederick the Great of Prussia, and was
requested to improvise upon a theme presented by the King. His improvisations formed the basis
of that great work. The Musical Offering and its story form a theme upon which I "improvise"
throughout the book, thus making a sort of "Metamusical Offering". Self-reference and the
interplay between different levels in Bach are discussed: this leads to a discussion of parallel
ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.
Three-Part Invention. Bach wrote fifteen three-part inventions. In this three-part Dialogue, the
Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A simple formal system is presented, which is an MU puzzle. The
puzzle is to figure out whether "MU" can be derived from the given axioms. The MU-puzzle is a
play on words and on the rules of formal systems. The MU-puzzle was originally created by
Emil Post and later popularized by Hofstadter. It is a good example of how a simple formal system
can lead to profound questions about the nature of mathematics and formal systems.

requested to improvise upon a theme presented by the King. His improvisations formed the basis
of that great work. The Musical Offering and its story form a theme upon which I "improvise"
throughout the book, thus making a sort of "Metamusical Offering". Self-reference and the
interplay between different levels in Bach are discussed: this leads to a discussion of parallel
ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.

Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A tiny part of formal systems, MU-puzzle. The MU-puzzle consists of
strings of letters consisting of M, U, and I. The MU-puzzle starts with "MI", and the goal is to reach
"MU" using only certain rules. The MU-puzzle is a simple version of a formal system, and is
used as an example for understanding formal systems, meaning and form in mathematics, and the
relationship between meaning and form.

Overview
Part I: GEB
Introduction: A Musico-Logical Offering. The book opens with the story of Bach's Musical
Offering. Bach made an impromptu visit to King Frederick the Great of Prussia, and was
requested to improvise upon a theme presented by the King. His improvisations formed the basis
of that great work. The Musical Offering and its story form a theme upon which I "improvise"
throughout the book, thus making a sort of "Metamusical Offering". Self-reference and the
interplay between different levels in Bach are discussed: this leads to a discussion of parallel
ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.
Three-Part Invention. Bach wrote fifteen three-part inventions. In this three-part Dialogue, the
Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A simple two-letter puzzle to illustrate the concept of strings, rules
and derivations. It leads to a discussion of meaning, and the nature of mathematical systems.
Chapter II: Meaning and Form in Mathematics. This chapter is about the MU-puzzle, and
discusses how meaning can be derived from form, and how the MU-puzzle illustrates that.
Part I: GEB
The MU-puzzle: A Simple Two-letter Puzzle to Illustrate Various Concepts. The MU-puzzle is
a simple puzzle given by Douglas Hofstadter in his book Gödel, Escher, Bach: An Eternal Golden
Braid. The puzzle is presented in Chapter I, and is a good example of a simple system to
discuss the nature of mathematics and formal systems.

Contents III
Overview
Part I: GEB
Introduction: A Musico-Logical Offering. The book opens with the story of Bach's Musical
Offering. Bach made an impromptu visit to King Frederick the Great of Prussia, and was
requested to improvise upon a theme presented by the King. His improvisations formed the basis
of that great work. The Musical Offering and its story form a theme upon which I "improvise"
throughout the book, thus making a sort of "Metamusical Offering". Self-reference and the
interplay between different levels in Bach are discussed: this leads to a discussion of parallel
ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.
Three-Part Invention. Bach wrote fifteen three-part inventions. In this three-part Dialogue, the
Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A tiny Fragment of a system called "Meditations on the MU-puzzle
and its Related Systems" . The MU-puzzle consists of the following: We are to take a string of
M's and U's, and by applying certain rules, transform it into another string. The MU-puzzle is
a simple system. It is a good way to start, as it is simple, and yet it can be used to illustrate
many ideas in logic and mathematics, especially in the context of the MU-puzzle. The MU-puzzle
has two rules. The first rule is: Any string can be doubled. So, if you have a string 'M', you can
make it 'MM'; if you have 'U', you can make it 'UU'; and so on. The second rule is: If you have
a string ending with 'UM', you can delete the 'UM' to get a shorter string. So, for example, if you
have 'UUM', you can delete the 'UM' to get 'U'.

So, the MU-puzzle is: Starting with 'MU', can you get to 'M'?

The MU-puzzle is a puzzle because, despite the simplicity of the rules, it's not obvious
---


---

Overview
Part I: GEB
Introduction: A Musico-Logical Offering. The book opens with the story of Bach's Musical
Offering. Bach made an impromptu visit to King Frederick the Great of Prussia, and was
requested to improvise upon a theme presented by the King. His improvisations formed the basis
of that great work. The Musical Offering and its story form a theme upon which I "improvise"
throughout the book, thus making a sort of "Metamusical Offering". Self-reference and the
interplay between different levels in Bach are discussed: this leads to a discussion of parallel
ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.
Three-Part Invention. Bach wrote fifteen three-part inventions. In this three-part Dialogue, the
Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A contrived puzzle that I will use to illustrate the notion of 'formal
systems'. Formal systems are systems in which you can derive new truths from old ones, by
means of certain rules. The MU-puzzle is an example of such a system. I will introduce the
MU-puzzle, and then give a step-by-step explanation of how it works, and its implications.
Sonata for Unaccompanied Achilles. A brief fugue which is a marker for the later parts of the
book, in which Achilles, the hero of the Dialogues, finds himself unable to perform the
fugue, much to the surprise of the Tortoise.
Chapter II: Meaning and Form in Mathematics. The notion of "Gödel Escher Bach" is that
every aspect of the book is based on an interplay between different levels and different
subjects. One level is the 'surface level', such as the actual words of the book. On another level is
the 'interpretation' of the words-something that is meaningful and true. There is also a third
level of the way the subject matter relates to the reader of the book. This leads to an
intuitive explanation of the idea of levels of description in the context of the MU
---

Contents III
Overview
Part I: GEB
Introduction: A Musico-Logical Offering. The book opens with the story of Bach's Musical
Offering. Bach made an impromptu visit to King Frederick the Great of Prussia, and was
requested to improvise upon a theme presented by the King. His improvisations formed the basis
of that great work. The Musical Offering and its story form a theme upon which I "improvise"
throughout the book, thus making a sort of "Metamusical Offering". Self-reference and the
interplay between different levels in Bach are discussed: this leads to a discussion of parallel
ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.
Three-Part Invention. Bach wrote fifteen three-part inventions. In this three-part Dialogue, the
Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A simple two-letter puzzle that sets the stage for the book. MU-puzzle
is a problem in formal systems. The MU-puzzle asks whether, starting from "MI", you can get to
"MU" by using a set of specific rules. The MU-puzzle is an example of a formal system, which is
a set of axioms and rules for manipulating symbols. The MU-puzzle is used to explain the idea of
formal systems, such as those that underlie mathematics and logic.
Two-Part Invention. Bach's two-part invented music. The story of the invention of the Two-Part
Invention is given. It is a way of bringing out the concepts of reductionism and emergence in the
context of music. The Two-Part Invention is much simpler than the Three-Part Invention. It just
gives the flavor of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter II: Meaning and Form in Mathematics. The problem of meaning and form in mathematics is
discussed. The MU-puzzle is revisited to show how formal systems can have meaning beyond
their formal properties. The MU-puzzle is a way of exploring the relationship between formal systems
and meaning. The MU-puzzle is a simple example of a formal
---


---

Overview
Part I: GEB
Introduction: A Musico-Logical Offering. The book opens with the story of Bach's Musical
Offering. Bach made an impromptu visit to King Frederick the Great of Prussia, and was
requested to improvise upon a theme presented by the King. His improvisations formed the basis
of that great work. The Musical Offering and its story form a theme upon which I "improvise"
throughout the book, thus making a sort of "Metamusical Offering". Self-reference and the
interplay between different levels in Bach are discussed: this leads to a discussion of parallel
ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.
Three-Part Invention. Bach wrote fifteen three-part inventions. In this three-part Dialogue, the
Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A simple two-letter puzzle to illustrate the concept of strings, rules,
and derivations. It aims to explain the notion of "formal systems" and the origin of metamathematics.
Two-Part Invention. Bach's second invention from the same set. More complex than the first.
Sonata for Unaccompanied Achilles. Aria that the Tortoise brings to Achilles, who is in the
middle of his "MU puzzle"-related thoughts. The idea of reduction in formal systems is central to
the discussion.
Chapter II: Meaning and Form in Mathematics. The Tortoise challenges Achilles to explain the
meaning of "meaning" in mathematics. Achilles takes a step forward, and is brought to the
difference between "rules" and "meaning" in mathematics. The concept of "signs" and "symbols" is
discussed.
Chapter III: Figure and Ground. The Tortoise's third challenge. Achilles and the Tortoise explore
the idea of "figure and ground" in the context of mathematical and philosophical concepts. The
Tortoise presents the concept of the "metastrophe," or the "breakdown" of a system, leading to the
idea of the "universe of discourse"—a term introduced by Frege.
Chapter IV
---

### Detailed Content

You are a highly advanced AI specialized in scientific and philosophical analysis. Based on the following text, produce a JSON object with the following keys:

  - 'summary': Bullet points summarizing the content concisely.
  - 'key_topics': A list of the main topics extracted from the content.
  - 'qa_pairs': An array of three thoughtful question and answer pairs that reflect profound scientific and philosophical breakthroughs.
  - 'insights': A detailed analysis containing deep scientific and philosophical breakthroughs.
  - 'paper': A formally structured scientific paper that includes the following sections: Title, Abstract, Introduction, Methods, Results, Discussion, Conclusion, and References.

Text:

Chapter XX: Strange Loops, Or Tangled Hierarchies 684
Six-Part Ricercar 720
Notes 743
Bibliography 746
Credits 757
Index 759
Contents III
Overview
Part I: GEB
Introduction: A Musico-Logical Offering. The book opens with the story of Bach's Musical
Offering. Bach made an impromptu visit to King Frederick the Great of Prussia, and was
requested to improvise upon a theme presented by the King. His improvisations formed the basis
of that great work. The Musical Offering and its story form a theme upon which I "improvise"
throughout the book, thus making a sort of "Metamusical Offering". Self-reference and the
interplay between different levels in Bach are discussed: this leads to a discussion of parallel
ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.
Three-Part Invention. Bach wrote fifteen three-part inventions. In this three-part Dialogue, the
Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A simple example of a formal system. The MU-puzzle consists of
strings of letters which can be manipulated according to specific rules. The MU-puzzle is a
strange puzzle that is similar to the one posed by Lewis Carroll in "What is the Name of This
Book?" The MU-puzzle is used to explain the concept of formal systems, axioms, and rules of
inference.
Two-Part Invention. A two-part invention that is presented as a set of questions and answers.
The first part asks whether the system is complete and whether it is consistent. The second part asks
whether the system is decidable and whether it is sound. The answers lead to the concept of
formal systems, axioms, and rules of inference.
Sonata for Unaccompanied Achilles. A response to the first part of the Two-Part Invention. The
music is a response to the questions and answers posed in the Two-Part Invention.
Chapter II: Meaning and Form in Mathematics. An essay discussing the nature of mathematical
truth, the role of meaning in mathematics, and the relationship between form and meaning in
mathematics.
Sonata for Unaccompanied Achilles. A response to the first part of the Two-Part Invention.
---


---

Overview
Part I: GEB
Introduction: A Musico-Logical Offering. The book opens with the story of Bach's Musical
Offering. Bach made an impromptu visit to King Frederick the Great of Prussia, and was
requested to improvise upon a theme presented by the King. His improvisations formed the basis
of that great work. The Musical Offering and its story form a theme upon which I "improvise"
throughout the book, thus making a sort of "Metamusical Offering". Self-reference and the
interplay between different levels in Bach are discussed: this leads to a discussion of parallel
ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.
Three-Part Invention. Bach wrote fifteen three-part inventions. In this three-part Dialogue, the
Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A contrived "game" which serves as an introduction to the concept of
formal systems. MU-puzzle: Is "MUG" an MU-theorem? Using the MU-puzzle, we explore
such questions as: What is a formal system? What is a theorem? What is the role of meaning in
formal systems? We also explore the notions of recursive and representational systems.
Two-Part Invention. The Tortoise and Achilles are back in this two-part Dialogue, which is a
recursively structured dialogue that is a "musical Offering" to Zeno's paradoxes. The Tortoise
wants to get ahead by reasoning, while Achilles, being a fast thinker, is dissatisfied. The
Dialogue itself is an example of the meta-recursive phenomenon. The story revolves around
Achilles and the Tortoise's race, with a clever twist at the end.
Chapter II: Meaning and Form in Mathematics. This is the core of the book, discussing the
connection between formal and meaningful aspects of mathematics. The Tortoise and Achilles
discuss, with the help of Escher's pictures, the notions of "meaning" and "form" in mathematics.
They reach a point where they are still at the edge of
---

Contents III
Overview
Part I: GEB
Introduction: A Musico-Logical Offering. The book opens with the story of Bach's Musical
Offering. Bach made an impromptu visit to King Frederick the Great of Prussia, and was
requested to improvise upon a theme presented by the King. His improvisations formed the basis
of that great work. The Musical Offering and its story form a theme upon which I "improvise"
throughout the book, thus making a sort of "Metamusical Offering". Self-reference and the
interplay between different levels in Bach are discussed: this leads to a discussion of parallel
ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.
Three-Part Invention. Bach wrote fifteen three-part inventions. In this three-part Dialogue, the
Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A simple formal system is presented, which illustrates the basic
notions of Meta-Mathematics. The MU-puzzle consists of strings of letters consisting of M, I, and
U. The MU-puzzle asks whether, starting from the string MI, one can obtain the string MU by
means of certain production rules. The MU-puzzle is a simple version of Gödel's Incompleteness
Theorem. The MU-puzzle is solved by the method of " MU-moves ", which is a term I coin for my own
convenience. The MU-puzzle is a good way to start the book, because it puts you right at the
beginning of the MU-puzzle and the MU-system. The MU-puzzle has two parts: the " MU-
puzzle" and the " MU-system". The MU-puzzle is a set of strings, and the MU-system is a set of rules
that generate the strings. The MU-puzzle asks whether MI can be transformed into MU using the
MU-system. The MU-system is a set of production rules that allow you to add or remove I's and U's
from the string. The MU-puzzle is a good way to start the book because it puts you right at the

---

Contents III
Overview
Part I: GEB
Introduction: A Musico-Logical Offering. The book opens with the story of Bach's Musical
Offering. Bach made an impromptu visit to King Frederick the Great of Prussia, and was
requested to improvise upon a theme presented by the King. His improvisations formed the basis
of that great work. The Musical Offering and its story form a theme upon which I "improvise"
throughout the book, thus making a sort of "Metamusical Offering". Self-reference and the
interplay between different levels in Bach are discussed: this leads to a discussion of parallel
ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.
Three-Part Invention. Bach wrote fifteen three-part inventions. In this three-part Dialogue, the
Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A simple formal system is presented, called MU. It is a contrived
system, but the MU-puzzle is an example of a simple yet profound puzzle that touches on
many themes discussed in the book. The MU-puzzle is an example of a Postulate System, and
in the MU-puzzle, the MU system is inconsistent, and it is impossible to prove certain theorems
in it. The MU-puzzle is a way of introducing the idea of a formal system, a set of axioms and
rules of inference, and the concept of undecidability. The MU-puzzle is a puzzle where there are
no solutions, and the reader is invited to try to solve it, leading to an understanding of formal
systems.
Chapter II: Meaning and Form in Mathematics. The idea that in mathematics, meaning is
dependent upon form, and that formal manipulations can create new systems that are internally
consistent, but may not correspond to any external meaning. The MU-puzzle is revisited here to
show how formal systems can have no meaning beyond their own structure. The idea of
"formalism" is discussed, which is the view that mathematics is merely the manipulation of
symbols without any intrinsic meaning. The idea of "
---

Offering. Bach made an impromptu visit to King Frederick the Great of Prussia, and was
requested to improvise upon a theme presented by the King. His improvisations formed the basis
of that great work. The Musical Offering and its story form a theme upon which I "improvise"
throughout the book, thus making a sort of "Metamusical Offering". Self-reference and the
interplay between different levels in Bach are discussed: this leads to a discussion of parallel
ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.
Three-Part Invention. Bach wrote fifteen three-part inventions. In this three-part Dialogue, the
Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A Simple Formal System. The MU-puzzle is our entry point into
Gödel's Theorem. MU. The puzzle: To get from MU to MUII. The MU-puzzle is a simple
formal system, and we should be able to understand it without any prior knowledge of formal
systems. The puzzle consists of the following three rules: (1) If a string ends with II, you can
add a III to the end of the string. (2) If a string has IIII, you can delete III from the string. (3) If a
string ends with III, you can replace III with a II. The MU-puzzle is to find a sequence of steps
that transforms MU into MUII, using only these three rules. The MU-puzzle is a simple yet
powerful system, and it is used to explore the concepts of formal systems, meaning, and form in
mathematics.
Chapter II: Meaning and Form in Mathematics. The MU-puzzle is a Simple Formal System.
The MU-puzzle is discussed in detail, and its implications are explored in terms of meaning and
form in mathematics. The discussion includes the relationship between syntax and semantics, the
importance of context, and the role
---

ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.
Three-Part Invention. Bach wrote fifteen three-part inventions. In this three-part Dialogue, the
Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A simple formal system is presented, called MU, and the question of
whether the string "MIU" can be obtained through purely formal manipulations. This is discussed
at some length. The MU-puzzle is a good example of a simple system that is Turing complete.
The MU-puzzle is a good example of a simple system that is Turing complete.

Contents III
Overview
Part I: GEB
Introduction: A Musico-Logical Offering. The book opens with the story of Bach's Musical
Offering. Bach made an impromptu visit to King Frederick the Great of Prussia, and was
requested to improvise upon a theme presented by the King. His improvisations formed the basis
of that great work. The Musical Offering and its story form a theme upon which I "improvise"
throughout the book, thus making a sort of "Metamusical Offering". Self-reference and the
interplay between different levels in Bach are discussed: this leads to a discussion of parallel
ideas in Escher's drawings and then Gödel’s Theorem. A brief presentation of the history of logic
and paradoxes is given as background for Gödel’s Theorem. This leads to mechanical reasoning
and computers, and the debate about whether Artificial Intelligence is possible. I close with an
explanation of the origins of the book-particularly the why and wherefore of the Dialogues.
Three-Part Invention. Bach wrote fifteen three-part inventions. In this three-part Dialogue, the
Tortoise and Achilles-the main fictional protagonists in the Dialogues-are "invented" by Zeno (as
in fact they were, to illustrate Zeno's paradoxes of motion). Very short, it simply gives the flavor
of the Dialogues to come.
Chapter I: The MU-puzzle. A simple formal system is presented, and the idea of formal systems in
general is discussed. Then, the MU-puzzle is presented, which is a very simple version of GEB's
MU-puzzle, which I will introduce in more detail in the next chapter. The MU-puzzle consists of
strings of letters, and the puzzle is to find out whether the string "MU" can be derived within the
system. The system consists of four rules. It is a contrived system, but it mirrors many important
aspects of formal systems in mathematics and logic.
Two-Part Invention. Bach's two-part invented music. The story is of a Bach fugue that is given a
counterpoint by a student. The counterpoint touches on Zeno's paradox, and ends with a pun on
Zeno's dichotomy. The theme continues in the next section.
Chapter II: Meaning and Form in Mathematics. The problem of how formal and inform mean is
posed. The MU-puzzle is revisited, and the idea that meaning can be derived from form is discussed.
The idea of self-reference and the interplay between levels in mathematics is discussed. The
example of the MU-puzzle is used to explain these concepts. The idea of recursion
---
